newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgaria lev falls further on interest rate cut.
newsitem.headline: Bulgaria lev falls further on interest rate cut.

text.p: The Bulgarian lev fell further to around 1,550-1,553 per dollar around 1030 local time (0730 GMT) from the opening's 1,543-1,545 due to shortcovering triggered by a cut in the main interest rate, dealers said.
The lev closed at 1,534-1,536 at Thursday's close.
"Foreign currency demand is running high due to a massive shortcovering but supply is very low," a bank dealer said.
A rise in free lev liquidity in banks was also a reason for the lev fall.
Banks had an ample lev liquidity on Friday after the Finance ministry rejected 77 billion lev worth of bids for short-term government securities in the past two days, central bank figures showed.
"Those free levs are now channelled to the forex market, seeking a vent," another dealer said.
The Bulgarian National Bank (BNB) on Thursday said it would cut its main interest rate to 4.29 percent monthly from 5.20 percent, effective from Monday.

The cut would further pare yields on lev-denominated, floating interest government securities, which have attracted foreign investors since March. The main interest rate stood at 18 percent monthly in March and has steadily fallen since then.
Those investors were a major source of foreign currency supply in the past two months but now most of them were not offering dollars for levs, dealers said.

Interest on local floating interest T-bills is pegged to the main interest rate and falls with each rate cut during the period to maturity of the paper. -- Sofia Newsroom, (++359-2) 911 88 (c) Reuters Limited 1997
